column17: the speech-to-text transcribed much more accurately when the microphone was connected physically to the device by a wire, as opposed to when it was connected over bluetooth.
column21: i didn't know that I could click on the cog in the top right corner to get descriptions of the terms. Though even then, I didn't really understand how changing factors such as the frequency or Q would affect the playback.
column48: I think it may be useful to combine the speech-to-text section and the text-to-speech section onto a single page, as they feel quite disconnected and it is unclear at first what the text-to-speech function does. Additionally, it could benefit from more emphasis on important buttons. For example, the 'Start Listening' button could be better highlighted to show users to start the conversation, and perhaps the button could flip colour scheme when it's 'Stop Listening'. I think the web-app is really cool though, especially the ability to save settings and set trigger words.

column13: It didn't seem to work on the browser I was using (Arc), so I had to switch to chrome, but that might just be an issue with my browser.
column17: If I set the language of the text to speech before starting to record, it would revert back to the original language, which got a bit tedious when trying to record and listen to text in another language
column21: Some of the saved trigger words weren't getting detected as well so it wouldn't always change to that particular saved configuration. It worked using the word "stop" as a trigger, but not using the word "passthrough"
column29: It would be great if I could save a configuration for the text to speech also

column17:
As my PC's language is set to German, the application automatically chose a German TTS voice. When i tried to change this, the old voice kept reading the full text before the new voice started anew.

I believe it would be helpful that the TTS voice selected by default be aligned with the language selected above.
column25: Not a challenge per se, but I did notice that when saving a setting with a default value for one of the configuration options, the corresponding cell in the table would be empty, which I found confusing at first.

column17: i think the flip switch can be explained a bit better
column25: there is no direct sign up button

column13: Not always 100% accurate in transcribing possible to due strong Yorkshire accent
column48: Suggest containers on main screen to provide better layout. Change delete button in profile page to remove the word SAVE. Needs better wording for changing from Speech-To_Text and Text-To_Speech. Possibly something like "Change function"? In the Text-To_Speech page make  the large font larger. Introduce a dark mode for those with more sensitive eyes.

column13: Where it said 'Start Microphone': the position caught me off guard at first - I was thinking at first it would be next to the 'Start Listening' button. That was only real issue I faced, otherwise it was very simple to understand.
column17: Not really, it worked really well
column21: It was really easy to use: maybe one thing which have could have made this even better might be a toolbar that briefly explains what the different properties mean when hovered over.
column25: What might improve the design is if a change is made to the default or currently used preset, then the save button changes colour or shows an asterisk to inform that changes have been made which might like to be saved (to avoid forgetting)
column29: This task was very easy. What might help is to have a button that plays an example dialogue on repeat and users can adjust the sliders to tweak for their optimal settings.
column48:
The colour palette could be refined so that each division of elements represents something more easily. For instance, save buttons having a different colour.

It would also help to add some padding around the buttons because for older people it can be harder to press on the buttons with as much precision due to the height being a bit narrow.

A recommendation that would help is asking people who fill in this survey what their technological experience is (eg. minimal experience like elders who don't use it much vs computer science students who are more familiar with tech): this could provide even more valuable insight to explain why some parts of the website are easy/hard to grasp.

Compared to other websites that provide similar services (eg. Eleven Labs), there are even more realistic voices that can capture tone and intonation very well, which can be very helpful to people who are hard of hearing as emotions can convey a lot of information. However, using these voices is definitely more practical due to costs (Eleven Labs can cost £100+ for its subscription for instance !).

This app would be made even better by taking inspiration from similar websites that are known to have very intuitive UIs. There's certain expectations about where items are positioned, the flow of reading, and more. So for some users theirs habits that have been built from using such apps thus it helps to follow similar in design to make it even easier to start using this app.

Having more font size options would have been helpful. For instance, instead of a selection box, a slider to increment the values might have allowed for more granularity.

I could hear the typing on the keyboard very audibly; it would be nice if there was a tick box that would drown the sound a bit. But I think for some people they might actually like the noise !

Overall, I think the web app is really helpful and it's really cool that it's open source. Thank you for making it !

column13: it had a hard time understanding when I used an acronym that was spelled out. I tried 'LOL' and it thought I said 'hello', Eventually I got it to recognise the acronym.
column17: No errors in actually reading it back, though it is a bit choppy, and doesn't feel like normal conversation.
column21: There is a lot of things to fiddle with, which is useful for usability, but can be confusing. I just ignored some options after fiddling with them once.
column25: I'm not sure what the trigger word means. I also am locked into my last saved setting, when I go to the dropdown menu and click on my first saved setting it won't register.
column29: None, it performed very well, still just a bit choppy, as in I know it is a robotic voice.
column48: Adding functionality to input pdf files or jpg files to recognise text and read it off would make it even better for both hard-of-seeing and the broader population. I would use it much more if it had that. If there was also a section where you could have a conversation between two people, i.e. two text boxes and you click one when one person speaks and click the other when the other speaks could make conversations between two people easier, because you could tell who said what.
